author: SafePit
title: Great Beginner Book
review: These LEGO idea books were a great idea and helped spawn other ideas.  I built most of the models in this book as a child and later as an adult using POV-Ray.  The nice thing about this book is if you have the basic sets, you can build just about every model in the book.  Some items are a bit hard to find today (fences and old style doors), but I'm sure you can work around that with some basic intuition.  Great for younger kids -- especially the smaller plane and animal models.  For more advanced builders with older sets, check out the LEGOLAND Idea Book from 1980.

author: J14T14
title: Classical Ideas Hidden Within
review:
I got this idea book used and torn up with a few pages missing, but I still was able to enjoy this book a lot. It was quite a bit different that my ISBN0756686067-1 LEGO Ideas book and I was really impressed by how good it was considering the age.

This book was released one year before LEGO got their patent granted for their minifigure design and all we had were maxifigures (one is shown on the cover of the book) and the predecessors to the minifigure, the LEGO-Land figure.

In the book, there are pictures of little builds that kids are encouraged to make and there are even some instructions included for some of the builds. I think that this takes away some of the imagination of the book, but it does make it more appealing for smaller kids so I will let this slide.

Overall I think that this was a really good book for the time, but in my opinion it doesn't hold a candle compared to today's books. It is a nice antique to have, but it is not much more than that.
